Ulasan: I bought this phone after finally having to give up on my iPhone 6's battery life. That thing barely lasted half a day and if I used something heavy like maps, it would be instant death. I wasn't sure what to expect from this phone, but I couldn't afford a pricey iPhone X or Google Pixel. I have been so far pleasantly surprised. I'd say this phone works better and faster than my old iPhone ever did. I can now open apps and type words into search bars without it having to think about it and my battery lasts all day long. It's also extremely touch sensitive, something I had to get used to after my less touch sensitive iPhone. I can't say good enough things about this phone. The only downside is the screen will be less crisp than a more expensive one and the camera isn't top of the line crystal clear. I've added a photo to give you an idea. Still this phone is great and definitely is an exception to you get what you pay for. More phones should be this reasonably priced. I will recommend to everyone who wants a new phone that feels like an expensive top of the line one but can't afford it. Also I had cricket and switching over was as easy as taking my SIM card out of my iPhone and putting it in this one.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
UPDATE (7/28/18)
The earlier performance issues I had have disappeared with Huawei's update to Android 8 - it is a snappy phone. So, from a screen, form factor, UI, and app performance (for the price) - it's a 5-star phone.

BUT.... What no "professional" review will ever do is tell you about the performance of the actual 4G radio itself - because that involves science. My experience is that when I transitioned from my Huawei Nexus 6P to the Honor 7X calling from my home tanked. I can hear the caller fine but they can't hear me. Because the Honor 7X is not a phone sold by the carriers, they don't support VoIP through the native dialer - so, many times, I have to resort to going outside to take the call or use WhatApp. For this reason, I'm demoting my vote 2-stars. So, if you're in semi-marginal coverage - be aware. (I also am starting to experience a lot of "GPS Signal Not Found" - which is highly annoying when I'm in mid-trip and depending on the directions).

UPDATE (2/18/18):
After having the phone 1 month, the one nit I have is with Android Auto on my Volt. Sometimes the 7x has problems keeping up (i.e. map screen is blank). The remedy is to reboot. But, I've had a love-hate relationship with Android Auto on my Nexus 6p too - not this particular problem but enough other things that makes me wonder how much real testing is done on the app. So, it's hard to say if it's the 7x or Google.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Unfortunately, my previous phone, the Nexus 6P (which was also Huawei-built) entered into the boot-loop of death this last weekend and I needed to get a new phone. Settling on a new phone is a life-decision for me because it's with me more than anything else that I own. I was looking for a short-term phone before the upcoming Galaxy 9 announcement and decided on the Honor 7x because of the reviews - the 7x was oxymoronically termed the "premium budget" phone. Once I bought a new flagship, I'd let the Honor 7x become a backup phone.

Wow - I was not expecting this phone.

What's great
* Built Quality - it feels like a flagship
* Snappy performance - enough said
* Headphone jack - I'm a big user of bluetooth, but many times I don't want the hassle
* Included case - another $20 that I don't need to spend
* MicroSD slot - I like the option of more memory without having to pay extortion pricing for embedded memory
* Low phone stress: At this price, I don't need to guard this phone like a Faberge egg (yes, I had to look up the spelling for that)

What's not great and why it doesn't matter to me (i.e. would I pay an additional $400+ to get these features)
* No Type-C: Yes, I'm trying to standardize on this but I've got plenty of microUSB devices now. I'm living in a mixed charger world for a while so I'm okay with it (but only this time)
* Not OLED: Yes, my Nexus 6P was brighter. But, fixing a cracked OLED cost more than this phone (so I lived with a cracked screen)
* Camera: I'm sure the camera isn't as good as the flagships but it doesn't move my $400 needle
* Bezel - it has a small bezel. Who cares.
* No fast charging: You need fast charging when your battery can't get you through the day - this battery will more than get you through the day
* No 5GHz WiFi radio: It's loading apps and streaming videos plenty fast for me now.
* No NFC: Since I can't depend on vendors accepting Android Pay, I've always got my credit cards with me.
* Not waterproof: I'll just continue to be careful with the phone.
* Not SnapDragon latest: As long as the performance is good - it doesn't matter.
* I can't remember how to spell Hawui: But, I feel superior to others in that I can pronounce it.

What's not great and may not matter to you:
* Comes with Android 7, not Andriod 8. Given that only .2% of devices were on 8 you probably don't care about this. For me, it's inexcusable for a manufacturer to release a phone on an old OS. This is why when I transitioned from Apple to Android, I settled on the Google Nexus because I knew I would always get the latest. As a tech enthusiast, when I read about a new software feature that's available, I need to have it. But, the reality is that, unlike the old days when new major versions of OS's contained exciting and life-altering features, the last set of major releases have been kind of a yawn-fest. But, it's still important to me and how Huewai keeps pace with the latest releases will be a factor if I choose them again.

Summing it up, great phone at a fantastic price. I would pay more if I needed to, but with the Honor 7x, it don't. IMHO, if you are buying a flagship phone from Samsung/Apple/Google, you're making a fashion statement.

(but, I'll let you know if I change my opinion)
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
As far as size, looks, screen resolution and touch response, the phone seems excellent.

However, the only reason I bough this phone was for the dual-SIM capability. What Huawei and almost every other phone provider doesn't tell you (and it takes a LOT of digging to find out) is that the first SIM operates as you would expect (LTE/4G/3G), but the second SIM operates ONLY on 2G.

No big deal, right? WRONG. 2G is being phased out in the US. In fact, the cellular communicator for my home alarm system was 2G and ceased working 2 YEARS ago. There is no 2G in my area. Maybe there's 2G in your area (very few areas), but that won't help you when you travel nor will it help you when 2G finally ceases to stop working in your area (and it will).

You can switch which SIM is the active SIM through the phone configuration, but you will only receive (or make) calls on the active SIM.

If you need a phone with dual-SIM and 3G on the second SIM, the Samsung J7 and one of the Sony's will do it. Make sure you get the specific model, as there are multiple J7's.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
If you have read any of my other reviews, you know I like phones and test drive MANY in search of really good phones, were kind of s phone family. Having said that, I am a Huawei fan since the Mate 2. They just build good phones for an incredible price. We have owned all the high end Mates and everything since the Honor 5 to this phone, the 7x. I say that to say, I don't mind paying more for a good phone...but the Honor line has made it so I don't have to pay more for a quality phone with really good specs. I never would have imagined a $200 phone could be this good.

The photos are a side by side comparison to the Honor 5, for size comparison.

The first thing I noticed about this phone is how remarkably thin it is for an almost 6 inch screen, with three cameras (two on back, one forward facing) It's much lighter and thinner than the 5, yet feels more solid in the hand. This phone has a nice large battery and I'm sure it will last my husband all day, with moderate text and web use. It uses a micro USB charger, which is fine for most people who still have a ton of micro USB chargers around (I personally prefer type C, but my husband hates change and likes the micro USB). Even though the screen is almost 6 inches, it doesn't feel too large..and definitely feels smaller than my Mate 9. The screen is bright and the resolution looks great. ALL my husband's apps and data transferred over (all 64 apps) within 16 minutes with the phone clone app that Huawei uses for data and app transfer. The phone is super fast and switched between apps quickly with no freezing or lag (yet). The UI is typical Huawei, but you can download the google launcher or other launcher of your choice to give a more familiar feel. We use cricket (which is AT&T prepaid) and had no issues with the APN, it configured automatically. Placed a call and the sound was good and definitely loud enough on speaker.
The camera is good...it's not the Mate 9 Leica but it's good and I didn't feel the need to mess with any settings. Is plenty good for social media pics, selfies and pics of the kids, pets, life's most embarrassing moments, etc. It still has a headphone jack, which I prefer to an adapter or even wireless. The finger print sensor is lightning fast and works before you even realize you have pressed your finger against the sensor. Not too much bloatware, certainly not as much as carrier locked phones! It has 64 GB of space, AND room for a memory card. Comes with Android 8 which is pretty similar to 7, but nice to have updated out of the box. It encrypts the SD card so be aware if you choose this option that you won't be able to just pop your SD card out of this phone and into another without changing the settings.
Time will tell, but based on prior experience with Huawei, as well an Apple, Samsung and various bargain phones, I believe this is another keeper! It's a shame AT&T backed out of the deal to bring this phone to the carrier, but it may work to the consumers advantage by keeping prices competitive.
DAY THREE of heavy use and no glitches, lagging, freezing or resets.
Love this phone more worth each passing day.
Months later and I still believe this is the best sub $200 phone out.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
I waited to do this review until after using with the EMUI 8.0/Oreo 8.0 Android update, as the previous Nougat software had some lag issues. On my phone, these appear to be fixed now.

The phone is smooth and fast for everything I do everyday (I am not a gamer). I have not missed the extra gig of ram I would have gotten with the Huawei Mate SE or the international version of the Honor 7x. The fingerprint sensor is blazing fast and accurate. The new face unlock, not so much. It works about 70% of the time. But for me it's not an issue. The fingerprint sensor not only unlocks the phone but can be set for other things as well, like taking a pic or scrolling in some apps.

It feels like a much more expensive phone. Solid in the hand, very much like IPhone 7. The screen is bright and clear, with fairly good viewing angles, usable but not great in bright sunlight. The speaker is loud enough but a little tinny, but hey, it's got a headphone jack, and good sound though it at that! Calls are loud and clear, GPS works great.

I like EMUI 8. It's fast and pretty customizable, with lots of themes available on the Google store. But if you prefer something else, this is Android, so there are many other launchers available. I do wish they had kept stock Android's ability to move apps to the SD card, however. As it is, data can live there, but apps cannot. Still, I've got pretty much all the apps I'll probably use, and still about 12 gigs of space.

The cameras are great for pictures in good lighting, with lots of options and a good manual pro mode. In low lighting things fall off significantly. And video takes clear shots and great sound, but no optical or digital stabilization, and only 1080p, no 4k.

Downside? No NFC (so no Android Pay), A Micro USB port instead of USB-C. Charging not as fast as some others. No official waterproofing (though there are some YouTube vides that show it to be pretty resistant to an accidental dunk. Not going to test it myself). Still it is amazing how much phone you can get for under $200. I would recommend it to anyone who does not need ultimate gaming performance, Android Pay, or absolute top-level camera. Or, If the camera is the issue, Buy this, and use the money you save to buy a real camera.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
For $200 this phone is a absolutely a bargain. Pros: battery last long, screen are big resolution are good....
Cons: no 5G WiFi and speaker is a little weak, no Android 8.0 yet. The GPS chip is pretty junky, I don't use the gos often so it not a big deal to me, other than that its a perfect one for the budget I'm really happy that I bought it.
Label: Positif

Ulasan: I bought this phone on March 6, 2017, I received 2 updates, currently with Android 8, Emui 8. the only problem is the GPS, it does not work with Google Maps or Waze, it is a pity that a quality team like this present this problem
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
TL;DR: Great bang for the buck. The screen is solid enough, providing "true" colors, viewing angles a bit weak. Overall call quality is decent. The exterior design is modern, looks like a flagship device, thin bezels, however, a bit uncomfortable to hold, wish it was more curvy. Performance is great for the price to performance ratio, wish it came with 4 GB of RAM, like what the international model has... Camera is great for this price range, strong in good lighting, a tad weak in lower lighting. Wish the overlay of EMUI was closer to stock Android.

After much frustrations with the limitations of my Moto G, trying to run two apps at a time, it was time for a much needed upgrade. I'm not a "power user" when it comes to phones, I just need something that works for casual use, and that can be a handy tool.

For $200, you're getting a lot of phone, thanks to the popularity of the Moto G, phones entering in the mid range market with a lot of bang for the buck, and Honor 7x so far has shown that is what it intends to do. The design of the phone looks as well as those high end phones 2 to 3 times the price, and the screen, camera and performance isn't so far off from those flagships.
The screen being at 1080p, and nearing 6 inches is still very crisp, the viewing angles are a bit weak, and the colors are not as "poppy" as more expensive options, however... the colors seem to be "true" and not exaggerated, which I personally like. I'm glad this phone stuck to 1080p, I feel like the higher resolutions showing up on phones are not really needed, and just impact the overall performance, and battery life.

Motorola phones, always had awesome call quality, I expect my phone to actually be able to function as a phone, crisp voices, incoming and outgoing, but for some reason, many phones fail at this, *cough* iPhones *cough.* The call quality on this Honor 7x is not that bad, could it be better? Yes. It works, it's crisp enough, it does sound better than some higher priced phones for sure, but it's not at the same level as Motorola phones.

The exterior design takes some elements of the iPhone 6, in fact a bit too much to be fair, this could be a plus for some, a negative for others. Although it looks nice, and modern, I hate the flat design; it's somewhat uncomfortable to hold, might as well hold a brick, the first 3 generations of Moto E, G, X had it right with the curves that blend with the hand, I wish more manufactures took this approach to design.

The performance of the phone is pretty snappy, no complaints for the price. I've been hitting my head against the wall using my Moto G the last year. It's really nice to be able to go through multiple applications, and not get hold ups, I really hope the 3 GB of RAM can hold up for at least 2-3 years, I'm a bit bummed that the U.S. model didn't get 4 GB of RAM like the international model(s).

Cameras aren't super important to me, I don't have the desire to take a picture of every food dish I eat, of every tree I see, ect... I think for those moments I need to take a picture of video, the camera does pretty well; in good lighting, the camera does a great job, in lower level lighting, it's a bit weak. Compared to the god awful camera I've been using on the Moto G, this is personally a big (MASSIVE) upgrade in quality.

I like to start off with a pure, or nearly pure stock Android, I'm not a big fan of skins over Android, most of them impact performance, and always seem a bit messy in terms of U.I. EMUI adds nothing for me, I don't know if I will eventually root this phone and clean it up, and/or install a custom ROM, if any actually get made and working... For now, I just uninstalled any of the bloatware apps I could, and disabled the ones I don't use, replaced the EMUI stock launcher with Nova launcher, and added a bit of my own personal touch. I wish after all the bloat manufactures add to there custom skin, I wish that they would have a setting where you could not only customize your navigation keys, BUT FREAKING RESIZE THEM!!! In fact, I wish Google actually would add that setting to begin with…

Honor(Huawei) if your listening! Two features I would add to the software experience is the resizing of the navigation keys, and navigation gestures to the fingerprint sensor: swipe left to go back, swipe right to go to recent apps, swipe up to go home.

Overall, great device, I'm glad I decided to purchase it, rather than going with a Moto G5 plus. Hopefully the device will last me for at least 2-3 years without much headache.
Label: Positif

Ulasan: I wish I could give this phone 4.5 stars. It's not perfect but for $200 it's pretty close. The build is solid and the screen is suprisingly good. I wasn't expecting much for the price so it has exceeded my expectations. The only thing it doesn't have that I wish it did is fast charging. I haven't had it long enough to say how big a deal that is but it sure would have been nice. The other odd quirk I've found is that you can't transfer apps to the SD card. You can store files on it but not apps which is strange. Again, I'm not sure how big a deal that will be over time. For the price, at least initially, the phone is well worth it.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
Here's a review from a total phone newbie without all the fancy, smart lingo that usually comes with phone reviews.

My phone history: I was an apple user. Had four iPhones.

So it's a nice change... It was hard to get use to an Android phone after so many years of using iPhones but here are the pros:

1) Big phone. Great for games, watching things and browsing. You will need two hands.
2) Soooo much storage... more than I am used to. And you can add MORE storage? Sign me up.
3) Definitely durable and comes with a case. I tend to drop my phones. A lot. So it was nice they included a semi-transparent case and there isn't any (big) damages to the phone yet despite a little slip from my hands at least once a day.
4) I fell on the phone. This thing BENDS. It contorted to the shape of my butt. The glass made it out no scratches. I just had to bend the phone back to its flatten shape.
5) You can withdraw your texts a few seconds before it sends.
6) You can do split screens.

Cons:
1) Camera quality is horrible. Selfie camera produces blurry, or at least not very sharp pictures. The back camera isn't that great either. Colors come out looking overly-saturated and doesn't capture a lot of details like I'm used to with the iPhones.
2) You cannot delete system apps like shitty Google Duo app.
Label: Positif

Ulasan: This is a beautifully designed and impressively priced phone that I would be more than satisfied with if one crucial aspect was present... It is NOT unlocked. I have spent the past two days trying to locate the source of my problem with my carrier to understand why my phone will not connect to my network. I originally assumed it was an issue with my SIM card, but it turns out my phone is still "locked" and will not be supported by another carrier until I contacted the company to resolve the issue. I reached out to them and did not receive any response. It has affected my work and I wasted $200 on a phone I had considerable hopes for.
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
OVERALL - Great phone for the price. As of the date of this review, the phone is hard to beat in this price range. The mid-range processor can handle most app's and games without issue. However, there are some issues that'll be addressed below.

SOFTWARE - The software, EMUI 5.1, will definitely leave you polarized. You'll either like it or you won't. It has an iOS look and feel to it. I bought Nova Launcher Prime and use that as the replacement launcher. The Honor 7x is set to receive Android Oreo updates sometime in Q2 2018.

HARDWARE - The Honor 7x has Huawei Kirin 695 processor. It's mid-range spec and is definitely capable of handling the day in and day out's of your average consumer. I've been able to play each game I've downloaded flawlessly. My issue is that the phone gets very hot in the back right corner at the top after an hour or more of intensive use such as playing a game, and I'm assuming the processor throttles itself in response to the heat, which will cause a noticeable performance drop.

There also seems to be random performance drops unrelated to what app's I'm using or how long I've been using the phone. They're rare but when they do occur, they're very noticeable and annoying. Sometimes app icons will disappear and will only reappear when the performance stabilizes. Other times there is a noticeable delay in starting apps after clicking them. I can't really explain how or why it's happening because I've been unable to recreate the issue intentionally other than when playing an intensive game for an hour or more and letting the phone get very hot.

BUILD - The phone is beautiful and feels great in the hand. It's not slippery feeling but is very smooth. It feels very solid. I used to worry with my last phone that if I sat down with it in my back pocket, that I'd bend it. I've no concern of that with this phone.

CAMERA - The camera's are average at best. They're not terrible. They're not great. The front-facing camera will get the job done for selfie's as long as you have good lighting. The dual-camera setup on the back is is also decent. With proper lighting and a steady hand, you can get some decent pictures.

SCREEN - It's not an AMOLED but that's not really an issue for me. The black's aren't as deep or rich of course, but that's an acceptable loss for this price range. The screen does auto-brighten in day light, which makes it a little more easily used outside. My only complaint is that the screen is very, very sensitive to touch. So sensitive in fact that if I'm scrolling through the app drawer and barely touch the edge of an app icon for even a split second, it'll launch. Coming from an iPhone, the sensitivity difference is going to take getting used to.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
If you want a modernized looking phone that can do the basics like social media, web browsing and e-mails, but less than half the cost of flag ship phones; this is a phone to consider.

-Looking Sexy
Back of the phone looks very similar to an iphone 6/7 with horizontal antenna bands on top/bottom,and thin profile. But also has a fingerprint reader.

Front of the phone has a very nice with bezel-less 18x9 screen ratio

-Screen Quality
No AMOLED display. so you're not going to have the best HD/4K movie viewing experience. But the 1080p LED display is very high quality despite that. Unless you're really accustomed to AMOLD Quad HD displays you won't notice a significant difference especially if you watch lower quality videos like on youtube.

-Speakers/Headphone Jack
Speakers are basic. Have one bottom firing speaker. As long as you're mindful placing your fingers when viewing video horizontally you won't have any issue.

Sound coming out is similar okay. Doesn't have enough bass, but loud enough to listen to vocals of songs and podcasts in a quiet room.

Has a headphone jack which some $800+ flagship phones abandoned for blue tooth only (unless you have an adapter). Very nice inclusion for those who still use wired headsets

-Duel Sim/Micro SD expansion
Self explanatory. Like the headphone jack, missing from most flagship phones nowadays

-Camera
Produces very good photos in the right lighting conditions. Not going to produce the highest quality photos like the Pixel 2, Note 8, or iphone X, but decent enough to share photos on facebook or instagram without being criticized about the quality (unless your friends are really nit picky).

Duel camera makes for a nice Bokeh effect (where the background is blurred, making more focus on the subject). At times it can look a bit artificial though (especially if the subject is far away), but most of the time it does it's job well. You can adjust this post snap shot.

No optical image stabilization when taking pictures, so best not to move around a lot for a second or two after taking the snap shot. You can use the finger print sensor instead of on-screen capture button to take pictures. Have to turn this on from settings.

Video is good if you have a steady hand, and not walking/jogging while filming as it does product a shaking cam effect if you move around a lot

-Finger Print Sensor
Works 100% of the time for me with dry clean hands. Scans instantly, no need to wobble my finger back-and-forth or hold down for a second or two.

You can also use finger print sensor to take a picture, scroll down webpages, or press and hold to pick up a call

-Gaming
Can run most 2D/less graphic intensive games really well. For 3D, high graphic intensive games; frame rate might dip a bit depending on how much is going on screen.

The phone also doesn't have gyro controls, so for games that requires it; it's unplayable depending on how much is implemented

-Operating System
Runs Android 8.0. So up to date as of this review. There are some custom firmware, but it doesn't take away from core Android experience.

It's mixture of iOS and Android leaning a lot towards Android. So good transition if you're thinking of switching over

An awesome feature this phone has is ability to do twin apps. Great if you have dual accounts for one app as don't have to switch users every time.

There is some bloatware apps, but you are able to remove/delete them from your phone, but most are very useful in my opinion. Best to test it out before deleting

Scrolling through apps is very smooth. May get a half second stutter if you view webpages with a lot of things to load.

There's no performance issues even when multi-tasking

-Works With T-Mobile
Have Tmobile as phone service provider. Network data and phone calls come through fine in my area.

-What it comes with
Phone, Wall charger/cable, instructions, and case. The case is very basic and makes the phone scratch resistant (minus the screen) in case you put your phones and keys in the same pocket/bag. I recommend getting a replacement case if you're the clumsy type and drop your phone often

-Missing features compared to Flag Ship Phones
Being 1/4 the cost of most flag ship phones like the latest Samsung, Google and iphone. Some features are bound to be missing. Here's a list of what's not included compared to top of the line smart phones out there:

1. No NFC. Not able to make mobile payments or physical touch data transfers.
2. Not water or dust resistant. Can get around this with phone cases that provide these features
3. No gyro sensor. As mentioned before may restrict some of your gaming
4. No wireless charging
5. Uses Micro USB instead of USB type C
6. No fast charging. Takes around 2.5 hours to fully charge from 10% battery life. Battery can last up to 2.5 days as long if you're not a heavy user. Idle time on this phone is really good. If you binge watch Netflix, it'll last 4-5 hours.

Overall, very good phone that's able to hang with the big boys (flag ship phones) with Android 8.0, modern exterior design and ability to run the usual apps.

Super affordable and excellent phone for the price. Highly recommend to anyone who just need the basics when it comes to Android.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
Overall this was an amazing phone. Was. Rarely had issues with apps loading, switching etc. Had plenty of storage to hold pictures, music and apps. Fingerprint scanner worked great as long as you kept it clean, and your hands were not wet or too dirty. Dual sim worked perfectly and was little hassle to switch between the two sim cards. Picture quality is fantastic, although it would be nice for more editing options. Sound quality was okay with the speakers, but I rarely had issues using Bluetooth and the headphone jack. Call quality was about standard, nothing out-of-the-park. It was hard to find a decent screen protector for it because of the 2.5D screen, the tempered glass ones never stayed on, but the soft ones worked perfectly. Same thing with a case, there are not a lot of options out there for a case. Battery life was nice, only had to charge it about every other day, with Wi-Fi, mobile data, and location services on. Without those running, it was about 3 or so days between charges.

However, this phone has barely lasted a year before failing. I bought this in February 2018, and just now in December it no longer charges, no longer connects to a computer. There has been tons of dirt and grime buildup in the charging port, as well as the headphone jack, which constantly needed to be cleaned out, which will wear out the contacts inside the charging port over time. A case that covers those would have prevented that, but there are very few options when it comes to phone cases. In addition to no longer charging, the phone will not unlock once the screen times out. Pressing the unlock/power button on the side ends up rebooting the phone and shutting it down instead of unlocking the screen, even with a single press. The fingerprint reader will not work either.

Everything about this phone was nice, except for the lifespan. Save the money and put it towards a phone that will last longer than a year.
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
I've been using this phone for about a month and I really like it. The battery lasts a good deal of time (around two days with normal activity, or one day if I watch videos or play games often), it has a nice camera and memory capacity, and very convenient settings. I love the fingerprint sensor in the back, it makes super easy for me to unlock my phone. I also really like that it allows me to call my contacts only by saying their name; everything is very accurate.
By far it's been the best, yet the least expensive phone I've ever had.
Label: Positif

Ulasan: If you are the type of person who doesn't care about brands and trendy technology, and you just need a good reliable smartphone with a good camera THIS IS THE PHONE FOR YOU. I am a college student at UT and this phone is my saving grace. It does everything my friends iphones can do (minus facetime, but my friends and I use google duo). My phone also has more storage, a bigger screen, a longer lasting battery, and was a fraction of the cost of an iphone. I can go a whole day and a half without charging it. For the record, I'm not just being idealistic about the difference between iphone's and this phone. The reason I even had to buy this phone was because my iphone 7 was a piece of ______. I was barely able to use the phone for a week. It was sooooooooo glitchy and the IC chip or whatever was faulty (a problem apparently VERY common to Iphone 7s), so I couldn't even make calls, only text. However, the phone I had right before the iphone 7 was an honor 6, which I gave to my younger brother and after about 2 years of use is still going strong. So, I figured why not just get the upgrade of the honor I had. Now I finally have a phone that works well. I would give this phone five stars, but its just a little bigger than I expected, but that's not really a problem because I also ordered a rose gold case with one of those adjustable metal rings in the back and I just keep my middle finger in there all the time so I don't drop my phone (its actually quite comfortable). So yeah I hope this review helps you make a decision and save your coins.
Label: Positif

Ulasan: Love it at first, but 8 months into the ownership, screen starting to detached from body. I contacted support and they claimed it's a physical damage that will not be covered by warranty. I have been careful about my phone and never sat on nor dropped it. There is not a scratch on the phone and no crack on the screen.

Ulasan:
The eye catching distinguishment for the 7X is that 18:9 aspect ratio screen for the $200 price point you are paying. But there is definitely more in this budget phone than just the screen. Inside the aluminium unibody holds a Hisilicon Kirin 659 chip with 3 GB of ram and 32 GB of storage. There is micro SD card support for added space as well.

And like all Huawei and Honor phones, the 7X runs a custom skin running Android Nougat called EMUI 5.1, which we’ve taken a look at often on this channel. I personally have grown used to EMUI and you can adjust the settings to make it more of a traditional android experience. Options are good especially for the budget field.

But going back to the screen, Honor is calling their 18:9 screen a “FullView” display which in laymens term translates to a 5.93 inch 1080p IPS display that has thin bezels on the sides. Viewing angles and colors reproduction are perfectly acceptable and are actually quite good for this price range.

Something else that is really good for the price is the build quality. We’re very aware that Chinese phones have been providing solid budget builds for years now, but never have they been easily accessible in the western markets. This is sold on Amazon, Bestbuy and basically every accessible electronics e-commerce. The only budget aspect of the hardware is the use of micro-usb instead of USB C. Although as I said before about this phone, I do suspect most potential buyers looking at the 7X are coming from a micro usb phone anyway. Its one extra cable you have to carry for those who have made the switch to USB C with all their other electronics.

The fingerprint scanner is located a little bit on the high side on the rear of the phone. I have to alter my grip to hit it. It is rather accurate and fast to unlock though. The 7X also has one set of fingerprint gestures that allow you to bring down and up the notification shade. Little features like this that it shares with it’s more expensive Huawei siblings makes this phone feel a bit more expensive than it really is.

Now the Kirin 659 performs nowhere near where I expected it to even when considering this $200 price range. Apps are noticeably slow to load and multi-tasking is near impossible on this phone. This is one of the few phones I’ve used the last couple of years which have fully locked up on me multiple times and forced me to do a hard restart. If you have absolutely nothing running in the background though, the 7X actually has passable performance in comparison with midrangers which is a level above its pay grade.

These mixed results play in with the dual rear cameras too. Like many of the Huawei produced phones, we have a 16 MP f/2.2 sensor accompanied by a 2 MP one that lets you do some neat things with the aperture. Oh and they look like googly eyes popping out of your phone.

The camera and gallery apps are slow to launch a majority of the time. What you see here is already considered fast through my usage. Even clearing up available ram doesn’t seem to speed things up for me. This is a big letdown seeing as the results of the photos are really good. I was extremely impressed with the photo quality the 7X produced. Landscape photos in optimal lighting are sharp and detailed with rather cool true colors. I’m going to have to say this is probably the phone camera in the $100-300 range I’ve used in a couple years. It falls short in low light situations and the selfie camera adds too much processing, but overall this was a reliable camera.

Another thing that was surprisingly reliable was the 3340 mah battery which lasted me for about 14-15 hours a day. I took this 7X and pushed it to it’s limit on my recent trip to Hong Kong and it kept up, at least in the battery life department. Almost 6 Hrs of Screen on Time, which by my standards of usage is very good.

My last couple of notes before I wrap the review up is that the Honor 7X doesn’t have NFC. Most budget devices don’t. I’ve been using Google Pay at ATMs and stores, and ironically in Hong Kong where mobile payments are a huge norm, I brought on the trip the one phone to test that didn’t have access to it.

I really loved this phone for a while until I started having issues. The camera is not that great but I did not expect much from a 200 something phone. It looks and feels like a premium phone despite being cheap on price. When I first got it, it was kind of slow when multitasking. Other than that, it worked fine. After few months, they issued a software update which solved the slowness problem. I could not feel any lag when using normal day to day apps like browsing, Facebook, photos, maps etc. Until that point there were no major issues. Then came another software update after which the gps started having issues. It would not lock on the satellites when using maps . Even when it did occasionally lock, it lost the lock pretty fast. I have had horrible incidents where I tried to go somewhere and the GPS signal got lost and I had to stop the car and reset the phone. I did a factory reset, calibrated the compass, used gps apps to reset the gps but nothing seemed to work. I went to online forums and other people are also having similar problems.

I contacted Huawei and since the phone is under warranty, they issued me a RMA to send it in repair. Now, I have to wait until I get my phone back. They said they do not have a loaner phone that they can provide until mine gets repaired.

So bottom-line, if your phone works, it is a great bargain, but if you have to send it in for repair, prepare to have a backup phone until you get your phone back.

I will update once I get my phone back.

* Update 12/11/18 : the phone came back from repair and they did expedited shipping. Now, the GPS works but it has never worked quite fast and well like iPhone and premium phones from the very beginning. I used an old iPhone 6 plus while this was going through repairs and had gotten used to IOS. After I got this phone back, I realized that this phone is much more slimmer and is overall a better form factor than the iPhone. However, GPS was always spot on, on the iPhone.

* Update 01/29/2018 : I am having same problems with GPS again. Even though the phone was supposedly repaired under warranty. Phone still has few days warranty left so I will try to send it in for repair. I am staying away from Huawei products for sure.

If reviews are important to you, then I'll cut to the chase. I love this phone except for a huge flaw that I want corrected. If you are not into texting, then I give you my 4.5 star blessing. Mazel tov! If you are into texting a lot, keep going as I explain my low rating...

As a person who likes to own her own phone and wants the best quality at an affordable price, I researched this phone for a long time before buying. I don't like to change phones often and I don't like being held hostage at a phone company with high payments for months! So after reading some great reviews on consumer and computer magazine sites, decided to buy the Honor 7x.
Overall, I really like it! I have to take all kinds of pics for work, so the camera function was one of the most important features to consider. It really gives iPhone a run for the money. The sound quality could be better, especially louder, but it isn't poor...could just be a little more powerful. I live in New York, so sometimes in a crowd, I just cannot hear.
Why the low rating then? Because their customer service could not give me an answer to my problem!!!
Situation: I text far more than talk on the phone, so there are two time-consuming and frustrating issues going on.

1. There are several colleagues with whom I group chat using the text app that came on the phone. (They all have iPhones -don't know if that matters). Whenever we get into a dialogue, I go berserk because if I need to scroll backward to catch the beginning of the conversation, then every time one of the others responds back in real time - even if just to "like" what someone else said - I can't scroll anymore because the page jumps to the most current comment. So I try scrolling again, then boom! Back to the most current comment. Cant respond if I can't follow! So I just drop out all together until they stop. Then they wonder why I don't answer when they needed my feedback sooner.
2. The second issue is along those lines, but involving all texts. At any time I want to review a previous text with anyone, as I scroll backwards, the page is jerky whenever I lift my finger up to start another downward swipe to scroll. For every five or so comments I pass backwards in a scroll, then it jerks forward three more (i.e., take three steps forward, step back one). It takes forever to scroll. It's never one continuous flow. Definite glitches.

I've had this phone since April, but kept thinking a system update might fix the problem and it never did, so today I decided to contact customer service. We did a text chat on their site. At first the tech guy more or less said it was too bad: it's just how it is....maybe I should try a different app! But I shouldn't have to ask my colleagues to install a different app just so we can have a flowing text chat! I told him it was unacceptable and that I would write a negative review on Amazon. So then he wrote back with some instructions to try involving the cache. I tried it twice and it didn't work. So basically I think the company's response is I'm SOL! To me that is still not an acceptable response for such a large company, even though I know in phone world this is a cheap phone! I had an Amazon Fire Phone previously for which I paid less than this one and I never had this issue!
If Huawei people read this and can come up with a better solution that works, I will be happy to edit this review and give a 5-star rating, because in every other aspect, I'm very happy with this phone, especially given the price. I had literally spent 3 months researching phones and felt like I was making the best investment possible, so to have this type of malfunction going on is a huge disappointment and a huge waste of my time when I'm trying to conduct business.

I've had this phone for about 7 months now and I really enjoy it for the money. I previously had an iPhone 6 plus that was just not aging well and needed a new phone but didn't want to pay the premium price. After looking around, I came across this one and took a chance.

I already knew I wanted to switch to Android so that wasn't an issue for me. I work in digital art so having a large screen mattered most and the screen size on this was bigger than my iPhone so that was a big relief. Finger print sensor on the back was much more convenient than on the front and I quickly got used to it. Love that it has expandable storage, a headphone jack, and is very thin and light weight. Not having fast charging or being water resistant isn't that important to me especially at this price point. I haven't had it previously, so I don't miss it. A lot of people are put off with it using micro USB instead of USB type C, but even as a former iPhone user I ended up with more micro USB cables than lightning cables so I'm actually glad I can put all those cables to use and don't have to carry different types when on the go. At the time of this review, most electronics and accessories still use them so it's fine for the time being.

Pictures come out alright but it seems like there is some kind of Instagram filter that makes everything paler and if anything moves slightly there will be a blur. Sound isn't great either and headphones don't make it any better, so audiophiles will be disappointed. My main issue with this phone is that we got the 3/32 version instead of the 4/64 version like other countries get. This phone lags and crashes frequently and I think the extra memory would've helped tremendously. I can fully understand having to cut corners and that there will be things that need to be comprised especially for what this phone costs, but if I know that other countries are getting a better version for roughly the same price then it's not going to get a five star review.

All in all, I am satisfied with my purchase and can't wait for the next model to come out. If you are like me and think that smartphones reached a level of refinement that works for you a few years back, then this is a great purchase.

The OS appears to receive updates fairly quickly from the mainline Android tree; I believe it was less than a week before Android Oreo was made available to users. The single biggest complaint I have now is the lack of USB-C, but that's only because the G5 had it and I was used to it. Using regular USB Micro isn't horrible, as I have plenty of cables available.

I'm not sure if it's just my unit, but the audio via Bluetooth is really bad. Tested across three devices and it just has a distorted sound through this one. Wired earbuds sound just fine though.

All in all, it's a nice, attractive phone for $200, but the poor wifi with bt on, and the audio via bt makes it feel pretty disappointing for my needs.

Ulasan:
I bought this Honor 7x to replace my wife's Samsung Galaxy S3 which stopped accepting charges even on new batteries - probably a worn usb port on the phone itself. When the phone arrived I could hardly believe the value for the money (under $190 shipped). The screen is nearly as large and crisp as my Note 4, which was a $950 phone when new. Instead of boring you with a repeat of the impressive specs others have rightly posted on this phone, let me share a sobering fact that punched me in the gut when comparing the numbers against "flagship" phones.

Three and a half years ago my Samsung Note 4 was $950 and Samsung no longer supports this (former flagship) phone. Even though it still works flawlessly for me, I will never receive operating system upgrades past Android 6.01. If I were to replace the phone today and amortize the cost over 3.5 years of use, it would come out to about $271 per year of ownership. If my wife's new Honor 7x lasts 2 years and we chuck it in the lake, walk away and buy a new phone, it will amortize to $90 per year of ownership. Another way to look at this is: I'd have to nurse my Note 4 along for over 10 years before the numbers pan out like the Honor 7x - all while enjoying a dated OS and no further factory support from the 2nd year on.

Meanwhile, cell phone CPU's, memory, camera's and screens all improve over time and new OS's make the phones more user friendly than the older "flagships" we try to cling to. Well, no more for me. I've seen the light and once I replace my Note 4 I'll cap the replacement at $250 or less with full confidence I'll lose nothing by comparison. As for my new attitude, I say torpedo the flagships and send them to the bottom of the sea. They've gouged me long enough.

Ulasan:
I'll be short and sweet on this. The device is neither thin nor thick, and its weight is more than fine for someone like me whose wrists and hands can support more than a pound of weight for more than five minutes. For its price the build quality is commendable, and my only gripe is the choice to make the rear dual cameras have their own assemblies rather than being under one piece of raised metal and glass. Dirt and dust gets caught in-between the cameras frequently enough to cause some frustration.

The screen is in some ways better than I expected, with only slight color shifting at odd and infrequent angles. Camera is very good and i've taken some very pleasant pictures with it, and I've only slight dissatisfaction with the kirin processor in here. The single bottom-firing speaker is... alright, i suppose. You really should use headphones with this phone if you like listening to music. Also, the bluetooth reception can be quite shoddy since it doesn't have its own dedicated band, and I've encountered several issues with perfectly fine bluetooth headsets while using this phone.

Overall, not the best phone in its class, but it's hard to with how good budget phones are becoming. I'm happy enough with it to still be using it and still want to use it for a while yet.

I'm returning it as soon as my replacement phone gets here. I'm sending it back for the following reasons:
1. The keyboard is annoying. It's a small gripe that I'd be willing to overlook if the phone were otherwise okay.
2. The camera is lackluster. I use my dedicated camera for "real" pictures, but this thing really does stink in less than ideal conditions. I use the phone camera to snap quick pictures I can send to family, but I'd rather use my actual camera and go through the hassle of uploading them to my computer and emailing them than to text dark, blurry pictures instantaneously.
3. The phone lags. I wondered what people meant when they said this and thought they were being fussy. After all, it's pretty remarkable to be using a hand-held computer at all. But it does, and it's annoying. I think that my keystrokes haven't registered and all of a sudden, I'm texting like a ham-fingered drunkard.
4. This is main reason. The call quality sucks. The people I'm on the line with come through crystal clear. I come through crystal clear to them, except when I don't. On several occasions on multiple calls, if I literally (and I mean "literally" literally, not figuratively) turned my body 45 degrees, my reception was dropped entirely. I could hear the person on the other line, but they couldn't hear me.
I mentioned this to a relative who is a huge tech guy and he had the same problems, but somehow lasted a month before ditching his.
He has a Moto E4 and loves it, but being a tech guy, is already planning on upgrading to a newer version. His girlfriend has had an E4 for over a year and loves it. I ordered an E4 Plus, just for the extra MP on the camera.

If I had problems 1-3 and the call quality/reception was fine, I'd keep it, but since its main function is so fickle, the phone doesn't offer any other redeeming qualities.
Label: Negatif

Ulasan:
Had this phone since Prime Day now. Had iPhones since 2011. No way I'm going to pay $800+ for a device these days. Never heard of this brand but took a gamble. I've been pleasantly surprised. Lots of pros and cons to consider if you are coming from an iPhone or you're just curious about this product. Just a side note, there is an option to unlock this phone using your face rather than your fingerprint if you like. It works quite well. I tried to trick it using photographs of myself and it never unlocked. It was quite intelligent.

PROS

-Expandable memory: I love the ability to store all of my photos/videos/music on a separate drive and never having to worry about running out of memory. This feature is like having a credit card without a limit.

-Battery life: I can get up to two days on a full charge. Sometimes I forget when I last charged the device. 30% can last all day. With the iPhone, that meant an hour or two :(

-Huge screen: I never want to go back to the smaller iPhones now!

-Speed: This phone is fast! Apps open quick and the fingerprint sensor recognizes your touch almost instantly.

CONS

-Brightness: Screen could be a bit brighter, especially in broad daylight.

-Bluetooth delay: My biggest gripe. If you have a Bluetooth headset, you will notice a delay in movies or YouTube videos. Read other reviews on here. It's just the way it is. Apparently it's due to the shared wifi and BT antennas. Nothing I have tried can solve the issue (developer settings, factory resets, different headsets). Restarting the phone will work temporarily but eventually the phone will delay again. Huge bummer since iPhones never had this problem. You could run a wired headset but who wants to use those?

-No NFC: This means no Android pay capability :(. I still have to carry my wallet around I guess.

-Camera: Like everyone says, it's pretty bad in the dark. It also takes really blurry pics if you have a shaky hand. There may be more settings I haven't played around with, but in all honesty I've been more impressed with photos from Apple's 8MP phones than ones from this phone that claims to shoot at twice the megapixels. Pics get much worse if you use the zoom.

-No wireless charging. At this price, I can't really call this a con, but rather a missed luxury.

-Vibration: The vibrator is much weaker compared to any other phone I have owned. If I have the phone in my front pocket, I will not even feel the vibration from a text message.

All in all, I only paid $167 shipped on Prime day for this phone. I'd buy it again even at the current price. Hopefully the manufacturer will read these comments and fix the Bluetooth delay and maybe I'll upgrade to the next version. I will wait for the reviews before I buy though!
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
**Edit**
Recommend going through Honor chat support to get ticket if needed (don't leave message on unattended chat - won't be answered). Turns out hotspot issue was operator error - I used a hotspot name my computer "remembered" so it wouldn't prompt for a password. Once I renamed it, it was fine. However if it had been the phone other than clearing cache, it would have required a reset - or maybe repair.

I think phone on "automatic" makes some pictures outside a little bright and tinny feeling right out of the box. That feels a little unfortunate. I'll update after I have tested more. At least this phone offers some basic settings to play with. The portrait mode doesn't always give me the bokeh effect. Again, more testing needed. I wasn't expecting professional but for novice was hoping for a little better point and shoot good results.

**Original**
So far, putting it through it's paces, I'm really happy. But I'm stepping up from $100 phones, with the last one still being on Android 5.5, so any comparison is relative. I had a great experience with Ting, including a free sim card when I asked them some presale questions, and the phone activated without any issues.

A clear flexible case for the back does come with it which was a bonus. The blue is a pretty color, wouldn't want to cover it up. Missed having gorilla glass from my Moto G a couple years back. So, pleased it is one of the phone features. Overall it's not too bulky for its size, retains the earbud plugin port, has a nice clear display, seems responsive and I liked the pictures I've taken so far. Nice options all the way around in this Android version 8.0 Oreo. Fast charging seems to work as expected with the included cord. Fingerprint scanner works great. Calls were clear both ways.

Have had a few glitches worth mentioning:
- does not support wifi calling (Ting does, so it's the phone)
- when I set it up as a hotspot, even though I created password and the icon on other devices saw it as locked - they were not challenged with a password request (have sent a message to support, so we'll see). workaround is to manually allow devices.

I'll come back and edit if I have any further problems, or get an answer to the hotspot issue.

Ulasan:
I value reviews on products I intend to purchase. Typically, I don't do reviews but I felt obligated to do so on this phone. I consider myself to be tech savvy but not a tech snob when it comes to phones. That being said, I know what I'm looking for in a phone and I thought this phone had it. I had been patiently waiting on the Honor View 10 to come out (guess I should've waited a tad bit longer) but decided to bite the bullet and just buy this phone until its release.

THE GOOD:
Beautiful phone- solid build. Love the aluminum body and how it feels in the hand. Love the skins and themes you can download to customize the phone. Transferring all of my apps / accounts / etc from my previous phone was a breeze and only took about an hour or so.

THE BAD:
I'm coming from a ZTE Axon Mini 7 which has given me hell with performance issues. Watch Netflix on the Axon 7 Mini is a lot crisper than this phone (sure it has something to do with LCD vs AMOLED).

THE UGLY:
RAM RAM RAM! Imagine my heartbreak when this phone started to lag not even a week after owning it. Imagine my frustration when I realized there was a Mate SE model with more RAM that was available for $30 more.

Needless to say I am in the process of returning the Honor 7X and purchasing the Mate SE. Totally worth the money in my opinion.

Ulasan:
I liked the phone design and it worked fine for about a week of light use. Then the first sign of trouble appeared - screen flashing purple streaks that would not stop until reboot. Invalid MMI code error appeared although there was no connection problem initially.
A few days later screen froze and unit would not boot up.. After factory reset the phone worked for a day and then froze again. From that point on the phone got stuck in boot up screen with no ability to even turn it off. Factory reset stopped working, clearing cache had no effect. HiSuite software was no help since phone settings had to be adjusted every time it was connected via USB, otherwise HiSuite would not detect the phone, even though Windows had no problem seeing it and accessing files on the phone.
Call to Huawei tech support, although pleasant enough, provided no solution other than offer of shipping the phone for repair.
It may be that I was just unlucky and the unit I received was defective, but since I consider reliability to be the most important feature of the cell phone I have to mark it as completely unsatisfactory.

Ulasan: Once again the Chinese have done an incredible job of giving flagship phone build quality with upper tier internal components as well as high end features like dual cameras all for 200 dollars. I ended up giving the my 6X to the misses as she really needed an upgrade while I'll preordered this 7X. They improved on the screen size as well as improving build quality and material feel. The slight curve towards the lateral edges of the device give it a pseudo S8 kind of feel in the hand. Side buttons have a good feel and click like a top notch device. The also went with protruding lenses in the back like Apple, possibly do to light restriction on the previous model when a case was used. Huawei also makes it super easy to put everything from your old phone to your new phone with their clone app that even a smart phone novice could do in less than ten minutes. Good job on making the best budget phone out there Huawei. You've got a lifelong American customer here.

Ulasan:
I've had this phone for a little over 2 months and up until this last week I was thrilled with it. The body design is sleek and looks on par with bigger brand phones, and the interface had all the customization I love with androids as well as being user friendly and streamlined like apple products. It was a little glitchy or laggy with some higher memory usage apps like Snapchat and it doesn't do "fast charging" like the bigger brand phones do now, but overall I was over the moon with the performance and design of this phone for the price. However, in the last week when I plug it in to charge I've been noticing it either isn't charging all the way or it seems like the charge has decreased. I thought maybe I was unplugging it without thinking about it and then forgetting to plug it back in. But today it has almost completely stopped charging. I've tried 4 different chargers, including the one it came with, and it does not even acknowledge being plugged in.
I gave it 3 stars because while it took a charge, it was an awesome phone for the price. However, 2 months is a very short phone life. So if you're looking for a high quality-for-the-price phone for a short period of time, this phone would probably be perfect for you. But if you're looking for a phone to last and perform consistently for a long period of time, it's probably best to shell out a little more cash for higher quality.

Ulasan:
I have always used iPhones and bought this just to try out an Android phone. My previous phone was an iPhone 6s. I have been using it for my main phone for a couple of days and I really like it.

Pros:

Screen - The 18:9 screen is big and easy to use. The text is much sharper than on my iPhone (407 ppi vs 326 ppi on my iPhone). The viewing angles are a bit worse than my iPhone, but not by much. The display gets just as bright as my iPhone.

Batery life: It lasts quite a bit longer than my iPhone.

Build quality: The phone feels like it cost way more than $200, however the matte black version is like a fingerprint magnet.

Buttons: The power and volume buttons feel solid and not mushy.

Fingerprint scanner: The fingerprint scanner is so fast and accurate. Opens in less than half a second. Much faster than Touch ID gen 2.

Call quality: The sound from the earpiece is load and clear.

Camera: The secondary 2MP camera for wide aperture mode does not do such a good job at blurring out the background, however the primary sensor can capture very nice images on its own, especially closeups.

Cons:

WiFi and Bluetooth issue: When bluetooth is on Wifi speed drops significantly. This is because they share the same antenna, but I was still able to play 1080p YT videos to a bluetooth speaker, for $200 I can't really complain.

Main Speaker: It lacks mid and bass frequency and can easily be covered. My iPhones speaker was much better.

No 4k recording: This is due to a chipset limitation.

MicoUSB: At least you don't have to buy a bunch of new cables if you have a lot of microUSB cables.

No fast chrging: It charges as fast as my iPhone with the 1 amp charger.

--- After looking at my iPhone after using this, my iPhone just seems so ancient.

Ulasan:
Either mine was defective or this has a 10 year old WiFi radio/receiver. I can't stream 480p or lower quality videos more than 10 feet from my router, more than 30 feet from my router websites take 1-2 minutes to load. I have devices hooked up all over my home that have no issues streaming video (Roku, game console, smart TV). I looked online for solutions thinking I have to be doing something wrong. Found a few (disable Bluetooth while streaming, software updates, etc.) but nothing made it better.

The display, which reviews indicated was a high point, is bad. Colors look washed out and muted. It has some sharpness to it, but the colors on my 3 year old Samsung J7 look much more vibrant. I tried messing around with all the display settings to no avail, simply can't make it look as good.

I give it an extra star because the design of the phone is sleek and the OS seemed snappy, but since it couldn't fulfill the basic promise of outperforming my outdated Samsung J7, it's hard to like much of anything.

Ulasan:
Past phones: Moto droid, droid x, droid x2 droid razor, S5, V20, Note 5, Note 7, Moto G5, and some other low end phones. Nothing beats the note 7 before it was bricked though.
I am really impressed with the phone for several reasons.
PRO:
The phone construction is great, camera is better than expected for a low level phone (about the same as the S5, but not as good as the Note7 or V20 and better than the others listed above), button feel is perfect, color is as advertised, screen looks good and the brightness level is way better than expected and much brighter than my Moto G4, speaker volume is very loud, but tonaly quality isn't that great but not as bad as others I have had. I really like the overlay of the gui and the options for customization are close to flagship level and equal or better than other big brands I have had. Response time of the processor is good and not a let down, the 3 gig ram seems fine for the phone also. Battery life is great and closely 30% longer lasting than the G4 I still have. The real surprise is the fingerprint sensor and how well it perfectly and instantly recognises several programed fingers. The Note7 was a joke in comparison .

CONS:
What I dislike is the fact the touch screen anywhere around the edges is kinda iffy, not really responsive at all. Using it as a hotspot is worthless as the speed is a joke and not even capable of playing youtube vids at a 240p setting. I still have 2 other working phones for a direct network comparo and this phone just sucks for use as a hotspot. My only SLIGHTLY MINOR COMPLAINT, is that this thing is slippery! lol Good thing they included the slim fitting, great quality cover/case for it. Given the battery life the last complaint is that it isn't a fast charging phone at all, but being that it needs charged less often that other phones I can still get a 12.5hr work day out of it before it dies. I have not charged it for 2 days on my days off, so the battery life is great in general, but having the turbo charge that other phones offer is still lacking on this phone. Again, just a minor con.

Overall:
I really like it and would buy it again if needed, but the lack of it being a hotspot is a big issue for me, as I used my last 2 phones a lot for this as my home wifi blows in some rooms and could use the phone to stream through the pc, smart tv, and the roku with ease for netflix movies. This phone just completely fails in that regard. Because of this I am wanting to give it 3 stars, but as it works so well in all other areas I will gift it an extra star and give it a 4.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
First.
Out of the Box. The GPS on this is highly inaccurate. It would "drift" upwards of a half mile away. It would never steadily track my location from the moment I turned the phone on. I factory reset the phone twice nothing fixed this. Also I'm located in New York City...this isn't pennsyltucky or the amazon river basin. I also set the GPS onto all 3 different settings (GPS only, wifi + gps, cell+wifi+gps) still...massive issues driving or using running apps. this phone in particular is discouraged by major running apps like strava for this exact issue (amongst others like the battery optimization garbage which i also turned off).

second. water resistance is horrible on this phone. i was caught in the rain. phone had a case on. i got pretty wet, that's fair but rather than the usb port being damaged or condensation in the camera the SIM CARD PORT someone stopped functioning? Sim card has one of those trays and is located 3-4 mm into the phone. "Water Damage" voided my warranty despite the phone becoming useless due to a sim port issue. I no longer could use my cellular network, otherwise phone was working as normal.

third. the screen is very cheap. mine cracked while in my jeans as i was sitting down. the stress of denim fabric apparently bent the phone just enough to crack the screen. i wear some tight jeans, i'll admit, but this has never happened before with any other phone, including larger ones.

i, like everyone who reads this, have owned a lot of cellphones. the issues i had with this one were especially bad.

I'd highly recommend a moto-g or LG aristo for simple budget phones that won't end up costing you MORE money like this Hew-way honor.
Label: Negatif

There are no great screen protectors for this phone! Not sure why. Best I've found so far is a skinomi TechSkin.
The only other issues are the sorts of things you expect on a $200 phone.
No USB-C
No fast charging
Not as much RAM as I'd like
Etc.
As I said no real issues yet, just budget level everything.

CONCLUSION:
Great phone for the price. Probably the best sub $500 phone available.

Ulasan:
Hey all! I hope you all find this review super helpful: I'm going to break this review up into what I consider the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. I'll reverse the order and start with the

UGLY: This phone is extremely slippery. It slips on couches, beds, tables, pretty much any surface. A case is mandatory if you want to keep this phone protected. Luckily, there is one included in the box! Because it's slippery it also gets scratched easily. I have a small crack on the front unfortunately after my 3rd week with the phone. Lastly, the charging time is unremarkable. If you ever had a Flagship phone and used quick charging you will be disappointed. This phone takes well over 2 hours to charge.

THE BAD: This phone has no NFC. Personally, not a big deal at all for me but maybe something worth noting for those who use Android payments. The software isn't like the Nokia 6.1 or Moto G6. Pretty much those phones have vanilla Android with no bloatware. This phone will have bloatware and that may/may not be a dealbreaker for you. Again, personally, I don't mind but maybe you want a smoother experience. I use Nova Launcher and I am perfectly happy. Finally, the phone looks... generic. There's nothing about this phone that stands out but then again it's super cheap!!

THE GOOD (MY FAVORITE PART!): Dat Aluminum Build quality though! Unlike my Moto G5+ (previous phone) I actually want to caress my fingers all over the brushed aluminum. It feels very cool to the touch and premium. Honestly, if I didn't know the price beforehand I would think this phone cost 2x or 3x as much! It's right up there with the iPhone 6S+. I know I just bashed this phone for being generic but the fact that this phone feels so damn premium for so little is amazing! The battery life has continued to impress me. Not sure what Huawei did but the 3340 MAH battery last easily throughout the day, I could get 40, sometimes 50% at the end of a night. And even in heavy usage, it will be at 30%. The near bezel-less display is amazing for a phone so cheap. You literally get a screen that's nearly on par with Flagships. It gives way more room for content and maximizes screen real estate. Oh, and movies and games look glorious. Tons of features!! One-handed mode, multi-window, Night Mode, double tap to wake, notification shade gesture using the fingerprint scanner, App Twin, Navigation Dock, and wayyy more. Performance is great and despite being a low-end chip I have experienced very little lag. Runs efficiently without any slowdowns. Anyone who wants a decent pic at a very affordable price is in for a surprise. After using Moto G6, Nokia 6.1, and even the Moto X4 from last year this is probably (I'm not a professional here) the best camera in its price point. Lots of filters, plenty of editing options, and the camera even have pro mode for further enhancements.

Conclusion: Even the bad things aren't deal breakers. I don't really need NFC (and I doubt any of you will). Slapping a launcher on this makes it even more customizable and smoother. The phone looking generic really doesn't matter when even most flagships struggle to stand out.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
I purchased directly from the Huawei Honor website, but I feel like Amazon is a large enough market and should get to hear what my experience was with the product.

In short, for the abysmally low price of $200, you will not get a better everyday phone for average media consumption. The screen is beautiful and massive. The performance, going from app to app and opening things one after another is snappy. Camera is just generically beautiful.

However, do not buy this for PRIMARILY gaming. This phone has a pretty good CPU, BUT the GPU (the hardware that makes a big impact in gaming) is quite mediocre. Now please don't think that this means it's bad phone; it's not at all. I can still play the normal, farmville-type games without any issues. It's just games like Asphalt 8 and such will be a little slow (But not unplayable, mind you).

That being said, you also need to understand that outside of gaming, the phone is spectacular. Smoother than butter, with minor glitches that any android device can have. Coming from an iPhone, I just love the amount of file management you can do on android, and with the large screen on the device, it feels like a legitimate portable "work computer." More so, the split screening and youtube picture in picture mode works really well, without any lag.

And good god, that fingerprint sensor is so freaking fast. It feels like the phone can sense your thoughts before you even put the finger down.
So what's the takeaway? If you're down to $200 - this phone every time. If looking specifically for a GAMING phone (primary use) - no, save the trouble and don't give the 7x a bad name. In fact, I think this is a great phone for grandparents, because if its massive screen, low cost, high performance, and the android "simple mode" feature along with floating docks and such.

Ulasan:
After years of running mainstream phones (iphone, Samsung, HTC, LG), I believe I can say "never again". I've only been using the 7X for a couple of weeks, but it's my new favorite. Apparently I'm not alone because my phone was back-ordered for a week or two. So far, it's been worth the wait. The phone looks and feels like a much more expensive phone. I don't do a lot of gaming, but everything I've done has worked well.
If you are coming from a phone that uses a micro-SIM, you'll need to get a new SIM from your network vendor as this phone only takes a nano-Sim, but that was my only (brief) hangup.
UPDATE(3/18/18): I'm still a fan of the phone, but one characteristic that could be troublesome for some buyers is the WiFi performance. First, it only supports 2.4Ghz wifi. This shouldn't be too big a deal, by itself. Secondly, the WiFi antenna is shared with the Bluetooth radio. This causes a significant decrease in WiFi performance when using Bluetooth. For instance, in my house, with Bluetooth turned off, I get speeds in the 22-25Mbps range (download). If I turn on the Bluetooth and connect my headset, that will drop to around 15-18Mbps. If I start my podcast player, so I'm actually listening to content via Bluetooth, it drops further, to the 3-7Mbps range.
Since most of my content consumption is pre-downloaded content (podcasts, mostly), this doesn't affect me much, and I had not noticed until someone else with the phone (actually a nearly identical Mate SE) mentioned it, and I did my own testing.

UPDATE(6/21/18): Still using it, still like the daily experience fine. Since the last review, the software on phone has gotten two updates, one to a "Project Treble" based Android 8.1, and the second update just a periodic security/bugfix update. So, I can't say I'm disappointed by the software support. However, in the last couple of weeks, Huawei announced that they're no longer going to support opening the bootloader on these (or any of their other) phones, so I'm not quite as happy overall.

Ulasan:
I've had this phone for a few months. Ordered it off of the hihonor website because it was back-ordered here. Since my Nexus 5x had bootlooped I couldn't wait a week+ for it to get here. Here is my review:

Performance 7/10
------------------
Does 90% of what I need it to when I need it. I am by no means a power user, I have no social media apps on my phone and use it to mostly check the news, navigate, and make calls. Biggest gripes is the occasional hang up on apps, where it will not load data when I tell it to. For example, sometimes I'll click on a link and nothing will happen. It's not an app problem, but a problem with the phone. Phone gets really bogged down if you are trying to run multiple apps at once (ie phone navigation, listening to an audiobook over bluetooth, checking messages). As many others have mentioned the camera is VERY slow. I am not exaggerating when I say it takes 10-15 seconds for the app to fully fire up and allow you to take pictures. Don't expect to capture any kodak moments with this phone.

Interface/OS 8/10
------------
I didn't really like EMUI, so I downloaded the nova launcher. A lot more slick. After making that change early on, I'm still waiting on the EMUI 8 update which I have yet to get. However, I am not going to complain much for a phone that does what I need it to do.

Price 10/10
--------
Probably best bang for your buck even after the complaints to performance. Will make calls when I need to and call quality is good. That should be most of the reason you need this phone. Uses google maps just fine and I have few problems running any single app. Not having a USB-C doesn't bother me, as most of my other devices are still the old USB standard. It's nice to be able to travel and use one type of cord for my PS4 controller, phone, and tablet again. I've never been caught in a bind because my phone takes 2 hours to fully charge instead of one. . .

Final Thoughts: I am not feeding into the phone consumerism nonsense, where it is now the norm to spend $600-1000 on a phone every 2-3 years. I hope Huawei can stick to releasing quality phones for under $400 in the U.S. I plan on using them for as long as I can.

Short and sweet: looks and feels great, unlocks quickly.

But this phone can hardly handle a few low-intensity apps running in the background. The navigation buttons feel unresponsive and often don't listen to your input.

The camera takes a good few seconds to actually open up, and I'd you're stuck in the wrong orientation, flipping it around from selfie to front facing will take yet another few seconds. By that point, the opportunity is lost or your friends are fed up with you and your phone.

Flipping between apps by double tapping the square is always a clunky, rugged transition, with animations skipping several frames. Switching between keyboard languages is also clunky and slow-to-load.

Coming from an iPhone digital keyboard, the auto complete is a huge step back. Misspelling a word, having it auto complete to a correctly spelled word, but it's not quite the word you're looking for, so you backspace to tweak it a bit, only to have the word revert to the original misspelled word, is way more frustrating than I thought it could ever be.

These all seem like minor annoyances. They are. But when they're all working in unison it makes for a very frustrating experience.
