Ulasan:
I am writing this review from using this phone as my personal one for a week.
I was really excited to try this phone out and maybe replace my iPhone se with it.
Here’s how it went.

The pros of the phone
1. The screen is huge, vibrant and beautiful. I am seriously impressed by it and the looks of the phones metal casing.
2. The finger print reader is amazingly fast and it so much better the iPhones by far. The placement of the scanner it perfect as well. Although, this phone doesn’t support android pay...how?
3. This is a half and half.
The cameras are nice but it’s kinda funny how this has an 8 mp camera compared to the iPhone se’s 2mp. Yet, the iPhone camera quality looks way better than any that this can take.

Annnnd that’s it for pros lol

Cons:

1 Camera: as I stated, all the hype not allot of preformance takes forever to try to get to the app and you can’t access it from the lock screen. You’ll always miss the shot.
2. Battery life: this phone drains extremely fast it’ll be dead before the day is over and that’s only light use. Occasionally texting and a couple calls.
3. GUI: the user interface is an awful experience making you go to extreme lengths to do the simplest tasks.
Very little shortcuts for cameras flashlights or screenshots. Basically all the things you need to do fast.
4. Maybe one of the worst things about this phone is the vibrating motor and notifications.
This phone always fails to show you that you have a text or a call.
No matter what you do it never shows anything in the lock screen.
You have to constantly check every single one of your apps to see if you have a new message. Example: Snapchat there is no notification and no badge app icon. You have to check the app frequently to see if you got one.
The vibrations motor, when it does go off, is the lightest feather-like vibration ever. You’ll never feel it.
So if you want everyone to hate you because you never reply...this phone is a good option.
5. Processor: the processor is really underpowered for what they are trying to make this phone do. Maybe this is what is causing all the other problems like short battery life (proccecor being overworked by its normal use).
From day one I had this phone freeze up at least twice a day. It’s very slow trying to run or send anything.
6. Speakers: the single down firing speaker is awful. The volume is very quiet for what you would expect from a phone this size. There is absolutely no bass and from an equalizer standpoint the sound it flat.
7. Micro USB port: seriously?
Micro not even USB type C? Not only that it is designed incorrectly so when you plug in a charger to it the cord will just fall out with the force of gravity on the cord. (Very fun to wake up to a phone with 3%).
Also, it doesn’t support fast charging.
8. Honor? Okay this phone and it’s software is basically an iPhone 7 ripoff. Literally everything. Even the settings menu is made to look identical. To think they named this phone “honor” with the absolute lack of it.
9. Hacking.
Very angry about this and it was the point in which I sent it back immediately.
When you take a photo it provides a location of where it’s taken.
Well when I started taking photos. Every once in awhile my phone would show that my photo was taken in China. China? I was in the U.S. not China.
So my photos are being sent to China and that’s the last of that phone.
I’ll upload the screenshot of the proof of this.

Ulasan:
Update 04-08-2018: I've had the phone for over a month now and it's still great. Every few days I have to reboot it because it does seem to slow down...but rebooting a phone every 5 days it's a problem to me at all. It does charge slowly, but again, not an issue for me. Plugging it in at 10% easily gets to 100% overnight. The battery life is still amazing. I use it heavily throughout the day and it's still at 50% or more by the time I go to bed. Typically I charge it every two days or maybe top it off a little bit if needed.

I had an Axon 7 (which I absolutely loved) but the battery would only last a few hours so decided it was time for a new phone. I couldn't find anything with the nice specs of my Axon 7 so decided to settle for this phone until something better came along. I was totally shocked how good this phone is. It totally buries my Axon 7 on boot up and is very responsive. I didn't particularly care for the UI so replaced it with Nova launcher. I was a bit worried whether it would work correctly because other reviewers said they had problems getting it to work. I had no issues at all. I use T-Mobile and MMS wouldn't work at all the first day, but by the next day it was working...not sure what's up with that (I'm using Textra).

The phone does lack a few things that would be nice, but they are absolutely not deal breakers. USB-C would have been nice, but I have a ton of the old cables, so that's not a problem. An IR blaster would be nice, but to be honest I haven't really used those on my old phones and they had them.

My biggest gripe at this point might be the sound. It's ok, but nothing special at all. Perhaps it's because I was spoiled by the Axon 7, but I'd rather have a phone with a mediocre speaker than one I had to charge 3 times a day.

The battery life is amazing. I started off the day with 67% charged. I listened to an audio book to and from work (40 minute commute each way), had waze on for 40 minutes, made a few phone calls and listened to music all day...about 8 hours (screen off). By the time I got home the charge was down to 45%!! This beats the heck out of any other phone I had and used this much. The phone looks and feels great...it doesn't feel like I only spent $199 on it.

The great part is watching others go spend $1000 on a new iPhone and realize that my 7x is just as functional and I could have 5 of them.

I am going to SHOCK many people who read this review.................. I bought the phone................. TO BE A PHONE. I want to call someone and have the call quality be GOOD. The first time i used the phone my son called me who was on a business trip across the U.S. from where i am. The call was so loud and clear it was as though he was standing a few feet from me. I want the processor to power through and not die on me and the phone freeze while trying to surf some website. This one has been super in that regard. From that standpoint this phone works GREAT. So the overall review for me is that phone, for the price deserves 5 stars. How could i NOT give it 5 stars? it is a great phone for 200 bucks. Unbelievable really. That is why it is so highly rated. FOOTNOTE:

This is a foot note my first review above. I have had the phone for over a month and it has worked just super. Happy with it as can be other then the negatives i gave it, which really were not negatives at all. Something i found out that worked for me regarding the BATTERY not holding up as advertised. I bought the phone with "Nougat 7.0." I took the suggestion of one of the reviewers that said they found that before you do anything, you immediately install the 8.0 upgrade. I found that initially my battery did not seem to hold up well as i expected. I was a little disappointed. I did as one reviewer suggested and reset my phone one more time. I noticed a REAL difference how the battery performed. No doubt about it. It made a real difference. 1. IF you buy the phone new do the update FIRST THING. Before doing anything. Ulasan:
Screen: The screen is bright and colorful, but I think it's LCD and not IPS as the viewing angles aren't the best, but even then it looks fine.

Camera: The default camera app is trash. I downloaded HedgeCam2 and activated Camera2 API and some advanced options like saving in RAW. In this mode, the pictures are really sharp and clear after editing them in Lightroom Mobile (Snapseed works well too). It makes the pics taken in the default app look like they were taken with a potato, especially in low light conditions. I really recommend taking your time to do this as the phone takes better pictures that you may realize at first glance.

The Dual Camera is a joke as it doesn't look that good, the blurry part looks more like it's 5 Mpix than 16. Honestly, it's just there for marketing, like in most budget phones, but if you're into blurry effects on your selfies, I guess you can get some use out of it.

Video: Limited to 1080p by the default camera app, you can go a bit higher with an app like HedgeCam2 (2048x1080 or 2K).

Speed: Seems fluid so far, but that's because it's new. I will update this review as it gets slower (or not) after some use.

Customization: This phone comes with EMUI and I'm not a fan of it, but it works well. Hopefully, future updates will make it better.

The main things you look for in a phone these days: Screen, camera, speed, stability. All of it is fine on this phone and for 200$ that's great, the camera is a win if you take your time to learn how to get the most out of it.

P.D: This is not my phone, it's my sister's, but I tested it just like if it were mine.
Label: Positif

I've had other budget phones where it just dies a horrible death within months (I upgraded from the BLU RD1 HD, which lasted me only 8 months before it became unusable). If you are looking for a great performer on a budget, this is a great choice.

The only things that I would gripe about (and they are really minor issues for me) are...

1. Setting wallpapers is weird. The image you pick will get LARGE, so if want a picture of your family, a kid, a pet, etc....a lot of times it will get cut off on the screen due to the warped size. Not a huge deal if you just have a generic graphic that you use.

2. Fitbits WILL NOT WORK with this phone. They are not a formally supported device. My wife has an Honor 6X and has the same issue with hers. Definitely a deal breaker if you rely on a FitBit for fitness tracking.

3. Some apps will not appear as notifications on the lock screen, but will appear in the taskbar when you unlock the phone.

The fitbit issue will be a dealbreaker for some folks but if you just want a phone that works fast, well, and doesn't break the bank....definitely give this phone a shot.

Ulasan:
I have been using the iPhone since the beginning. I have never owned an Android device so I can’t compare it to others. I even have the iPhone X. The reason I purchased this was I wanted a phone with dual sims. I hate carrying around two devices. I did a lot of research and wanted a good value. This phone fit the bill.
It will work with any gsm network. T-Mobile, AT&T and other prepaid gsm providers in the US.
Pros-
Fingerprint sensor is lighting fast!
Camera is pretty good.
Screen looks great
The phone is pretty snappy as far as speed. No real lag. I am using the stock software and from what I have read installing different launchers can slow it down.

Cons-
No 5ghz WiFi.
No fast charge, it takes a long time to fully charge.
No wifi calling
Second sim only 2G, you can still text but I don’t know if it can handle picture messages on 2G
No native mail app. You must use a third party mail app. Yahoo, google.
I think it has some form of ad software installed.
The usb connection to most new car radios does not allow you to play music or streaming apps from the phone. That can only be done with Bluetooth. This might just be an Android thing and not a phone thing. My iPhones have always worked with the usb connection.

Android messages.. this is by far the worst feature of an Android phone. There is no comparison to iMessage on the iPhone. It has limited features and a character limit.. seriously? Its 2018 and text are limited to 160 characters ??. If you are a heavy texter which I am not, Android isn’t for you if you are coming from an iPhone.
I guess some of my review is about the Android 7 OS. ??
I feel like I am using Windoze again. It’s not too bad but If you are tech savvy you can figure it out.
I’ll keep using it for a couple of weeks and if my opinion changes I’ll update my review.

If you are looking for a good value then this is the phone for you. For $200, you can’t go wrong.

UPDATE..

Well, I spoke to soon.. I am returning the phone.
It is now locking up. I have to constantly reboot it, I have had to reset it and when I install a few apps it starts happening again. I am guessing it’s the Android OS that is the problem but.. if the OS won’t run correctly it doesn’t matter how good the hardware is.
I am not a gamer or a frequent texter.. I do use a few social media apps and shopping apps, that’s about it..
still a good value if you can deal with the android OS.

I've owned the Honor 6x in the past, and since it worked for me I was pretty confident the 7x would be no different. With prices of phones getting higher and higher I was looking for something that wasn't so expensive; I'd just returned the Mate 10 Pro for this very reason and decided to stick with Honor/Huawei.

I love that it gets VoLTE on my carrier (T-mobile), and that it includes a case in the box - definitely something other phone companies need to do. The handfeel is a HUGE improvement over the 6x, and though it's not what the market considers premium (glass) I like that if I went without a case the device would probably be ok too.

So far battery life has been about what my 6x was able to do, and for my usage/needs that's more than enough - I can get through a day in with 60% remaining, and that suites me just fine. I'm not a gamer, my apps are mostly time killers/utility apps, but I haven't had the device slow when switching or freeze while trying to load something.

EMUI isn't something that's a deal breaker for me, in fact I love that it has features that I sometimes have to unlock with an app or ADB on other devices (night mode, fingerprint scanner gestures, mobile hotspot toggle, data toggle, etc); about the only thing I wish it would include is the ability to load customer icons and/or make the default icons smaller.

Overall for what I paid for the phone I'm extremely satisfied right now, even if it does get an Android 8.0 update I'll still consider this money well spent as the feature set is pretty killer. There's some good competition in this space, so definitely look around but I'm happy with my purchase.

Ulasan:
I'm holding off on giving this phone a 5 until I get more time with it, as it just arrived today. If you get blue, be aware it's a darker blue than the picture would suggest. It's more of a navy than a bright blue, but that's fine with me. I haven't tested the wifi as of yet, so I can't verify any claims about how good/bad it is. Pro's and Con's so far:

Pros:
- Contrary to some things I've been reading, we ordered two of these, one black and one blue, and both are getting 4g service through AT&T, so that hasn't been a problem for us.
- The fingerprint sensor is SUPER snappy so far, by far the fastest way to unlock the phone, and to my pleasant surprise you can register up to 5 fingers in the settings, so multiple people can be given permissions to unlock the phone with that option if you so choose, which is incredibly nice. It's also good to note that out of the box the phone has the option to toggle on and off extra functions for that sensor, which lets you answer calls, pull down the notification menu, etc., which is quite convenient.
-The phone feels well constructed, and the aluminum body makes it feel stout. It's been in my pocket (with thin rigid case and screen protector) through work and I've stopped worrying for the most part about accidentally cracking the screen. The phone is quite rigid and feels durable.
-The camera is great. There's a plethora of features built in with Huawei's software, and it's given me some amazing shots (I'll include at least one with this updated review). It'll take some experimenting to get used to, and it will also take practice to learn what works best when, but overall I'm extremely happy. It won't do 4k or anything that great, but I hardly expected it to.
-For a "cheap" phone the speakers are more than passable. You won't get amazing depth of sound or anything (these are phone speakers, after all) but audio is clear and loud enough for my uses.
- I've yet to get this phone under %50 battery, but I'm not a power user. It's greatest test so far as been as a GPS device for about a 4hr round trip, with the screen on about 3/4 of that time along with my normal light use. Heavy users will likely have more problems with it, but if you manage how many things you have going on in the background it's not a problem.
-I cannot complain at all about screen quality here. If anything I'm thoroughly impressed. Colors are true, lines are crisp, and it responds to touch without issue. It looks beautiful.

Cons:
-The first minor thing is that if you're ordering it for AT&T you might need to mess with some APN settings when you first set it up. It's an inconvenience but nothing serious that other phones don't also have to deal with.
-I do have one mildly irritating issue with headphone audio, which honestly is barely worth mentioning. I think it's due to the phone turning off power to audio devices to conserve battery life, but when I have headphones in (and only then), a second or two after audio is stopped there's a squeak or pop. It's the same noise you would hear plugging headphones into the headphone jack or wiggling the wire on a dying pair of headphones to get it to reconnect and play sound. It's slightly irritating, but not enough to dampen my enjoyment of this phone.
-Some will consider this a Con, but I don't mind it personally. As of now this phone is still running Android 7.0 Nougat, without an option to upgrade to the newest Oreo software. This is supposed to change, however I haven't found a solid date on when the update will roll out to this device.
- The phone does not support USB type C. This doesn't bother me in the least, but some people prefer it for various (legitimate) reasons.

Overall, this is an amazing device for the cost, and I can't recommend it enough. It doesn't help that I'm still getting a kick out of showing it to people and seeing the look of shocked disbelief on their faces when I inform them that this sleek, snappy device is a Huawei, which in my area has a reputation for being the bad end of cheap. Holding it up to a friend's Samsung Galaxy Note 8, it's nearly identical in size, and in brief comparison seemed just as high quality, and it's a surprise to people that it's not a flagship phone.

Ulasan:
I've had this phone over a week now and like it more each day. I had been attached to my HTC One M9 but it had contracted degenerative terminal battery disease; symptoms include spontaneous power off and battery standby of an hour or less. As the disease ran it's inevitable course I knew I had to replace it. Investigation of possible battery transplant offered little hope. The new HTC U11 was way out of my price range also one thing I really wanted was offline FM radio and because wireless companies prefer that you use data it's frequently only on one-off brands and cheap phones. I kept running across the Huawei honor7x. While there are some scathing reviews, there are some scathing reviews for every phone so the percentage of good reviews must be taken into consideration. The screen quality, camera, battery, processor & GPU, my offline FM radio, and Tricorde-resque plethora of sensors, overall build tells me I've made the right decision. Since receiving it Wednesday I've charged it 3 times. I was charging my HTC 3-6 times per day and even that was insufficient. The complaints in the harsher reviews of the Huawei honor7x frequently indicate "lagging" but they also say it's resolved by a reboot, " only to return again at some point in the future.
So for a $200 phone with premium features, occasionally one may have to turn it off then on again. THE HORROR!!
Others dislike the micro USB vs USB-C. I personally am relieved I don't need to replace my numerous charging cables. Also, complaints about no Qualcomm quick charge.
With light to moderate use, the H7X lasts me 3 days between charges. Also, it's 1/4 the price of a premium phone. If they are going to omit something I'm glad it's that. What else? Oh no wireless charging either. While inductive oscillating charging is kinda neat, it's slow, hard on circuitry due to heat and testy, if your device isn't right on the correct spot it doesn't charge so you just put your phone down for a while, which can be a good thing on its own, but it still needs changing. So again, it's$200, and if you feel that strongly about wireless charging you can buy a kit. Personally I think my $200 phone should go to work for me in the morning so I can sleep, keep me sexually gratified and cook my dinner, but that's not what phones do. Conversely, if you are not willing to spend close to $1000 on a phone there are some things that you are going to have to do without. That being said, the H7X isn't really a compromise, you are getting far more for your money in my book! Thank you Huawei! Excellent phone at an excellent value!

Ulasan:
UPDATED REVIEW:

Changing my four star review after a month of solid use to a measly two stars. The original review is below. After a month of use, about half the time the phone locks up. You can have about three or four windows open at a time before things start getting a little unusable. Sometimes it'll happen with just a single window open and sometimes it will happen with NO WINDOWS open. Still, this is not the worse part. The worse part is that the phone and/or apps will become unresponsive without you knowing. Many times, my Nike Run Club has crashed and missed 15-30 minutes worth of my run because it crashed and the phone still showed the app running in the background. I never had the same issue with my Axon 7 or my Galaxy S7. Using GPS to get to a work-site you've never been before? Good luck. Same problem happens.

The sound and video quality remains solid and I still think the phone itself is absolutely BEAUTIFUL.

Although this is nothing against the phone itself, I am unable to find tempered glass that will stay on longer than two weeks which leaves my phone vulnerable to damage at super inconvenient times and forces me to rush order new tempered glass so that I can preserve it as much as I can. It's disappointing that not many manufacturers are manufacturing good quality accessories for this device. Again, nothing against the phone but if you really want to protect it, there's not many good options that will work long enough to be worth it.

I kept thinking to myself, how can a phone this beautiful have such subpar performance on a regular basis? I get overheating phones, or having way too many apps and windows open, or trying to do too much at a single time but this phone can barely handle an email window open, a browser in the background, and a water time app waiting in the background for my water intake. Save yourself some headache and buy something different. I'm going to have to replace it with something that can handle my typical usage, which believe me, is not crazy. I mostly use my phone for work. At most it'll have my work app, my work email, and a browser open. Even then it suffers in performance. If you're a power user or use your phone a lot for everything or just use your phone in moderation, this is a hard pass. If you only ever have one or two apps open at most, and you're okay with your phone locking up at any time for any reason, then you'll probably get by.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

For $200.00, you can't beat the quality.

Especially when you first setup the phone, the phone will be under a great deal of load. It's a no-brainer since your phone is usually installing all of your apps from your previous phone and the corresponding updates for the system as well. Still, even casual use will lock up the phone. This isn't a huge deal. Close your 4 million apps and try performing the same task again, it should work without issue. That being said, as someone who needs to use this phone for IT work, the lock up can be frustrating sometimes. If you're on a budget and you want a little better performance, plop down the extra $30 and go for the 4GB, 64GB version of this phone found here (trust me, I wish I had done the same but it's not worth the effort just yet): Huawei Mate SE Factory Unlocked 5.93" - 4GB/64GB Octa-core Processor| 16MP + 2MP Dual Camera| Grey (US Warranty)

The 5.93" phone screen is AMAZING. I put it right next to my brother's iPhone X, who by the way had been bragging about his new iPhone X for months, and he went quiet before releasing a subtle "wow." When I told him how much money it cost, he shook his head in disbelief. Screen transitions can be customized, you can add 5x6 app tiles, and the stock backgrounds and lock screens are visually pleasing to look at. Sometimes I find myself waking my phone just to remind myself of how awesome the phone really is.

Storage is a bit of a bust. The system takes about half the storage of the phone. If you buy a 32GB, be ready to have about 18GB of storage to actually use. Again, if you're on a budget but you need double the storage, check the link I posted earlier because that is the exact same phone with an extra GB of RAM and an extra 32GB of storage on top of what this phone currently has.

My only regret is that I didn't upgrade for $30 to 4GB RAM and 64GB of storage but you can be assured that once you have this phone, you'll forget what a galaxy or iPhone is, or why they even exist.

Ulasan:
Update (4 days later after purchase)
Unfortunately, I had to drop 2 stars after using the phone for 4 days. I started to hit serious lag. It seems like reviews you may find on youtube are reviewing the 4GB/64GB international version, because the US version with the 3GB/32GB is just not on par with the international version.
Why I dropped 2 stars?
- No 5ghz wifi connectivity. This is a serious bummer, since I only connect to the 5ghz frequency on my home wifi, since I had problems with other devices connecting and my wifi router routinely dropping some off the wifi-list,unless it's on the 5ghz freq. This is kinda interesting, since as far as I can remember, even phones from 2014 had ac 5ghz option.
- Extremely slow charging. I just can't get around with this. I can see people charging their phones at night, but there are phones out now with the same $200+ price range that do fast charging. Micro USB is one thing, there are phones that fast-charge with it, but again, we are in 2018.
- No NFC. Granted, there are only a few budget phones with NFC, but we need to look at from the point of view of the year 2018 just began and within a few months, more budget phones are coming out, packed with more features than ever before, even with NFC. Let this be the least of the problems, it's a compromise that most people can live with, if they don't use NFC (not using their phones with Google Play or transfer files etc. )
- Here is the worst. After several days, the phone began to lag. Whether it's from the new update, that popped up during setup, whether it's something to do with lesser memory than most phones or the interface itself, I don't know. I ended up disabling apps to gain some speed back, including disabling amazon apps, navigation apps and the built in Huawei apps. Then it continued. Browsing a webpage is like the scrolling acceleration is disabled or just the lag gets worse. Keep shutting down recently used apps won't help. Rebooting won't help, there is a constant lag while browsing in Chrome and in Facebook, something I don't experience in other budget phones for years now. Hopefully Huawei can address this in future updates, or could be just a few particular models effected, I don't know. It can get very annoying. There is something going on with the memory management, whatever, I am not an expert, but it just ruins the experience.
Speaker is ok, but still very tiny sound. Again, we are talking about a $200 phone, but consider the trade-offs.
In a nutshell, here is what to keep an eye out for when purchasing this phone:
+Nice bright screen, small bezels,
+Good camera for the price
+notification LED (many people prefer it)
+battery lasts a day for most people
+fingerprint reader is lightning fast
+Love/Hate heavy launcher skin over Android OS
---------------------------------------------------------------
- Lag can creep up after a certain amount time, restart needed, apps needs to be disabled, /wait for more updates?/
- Still on Android Nougat, no confirmed date for Oreo update
- Heavy launcher skin over Android OS
- No dual band wifi
-No NFC
-US version : 3GB RAM/32GB of onboard space
-Micro USB
-No fast charging
-No 4K recording capability
-No image stabilization
-tiny single speaker at the bottom
----------------------------------
At this point, I had luck to use the Honor 6X for 2 weeks last year and it was great. I would recommend that phone over this one.

Ulasan:
My first impression of this phone was that it’s a great phone which rival’s phones that cost double its price. Both the build quality and display are premium. Initially, I was a little worried about purchasing a phone with something other than stock Android on it since that’s what my previous phone (a Nexus 5x) was running, but the EMUI interface isn’t bad at all and I didn’t consider it a downgrade once I used it.

The Honor 7x ships with a little bloatware installed, most of which can be removed. Some apps such as SwiftKey cannot be uninstalled, although you can set the default to the Google keyboard app instead. The phone also ships with a clear case that’s good enough to use until you know you’re going to keep the phone.

I spent almost an entire day getting everything setup only to later discover that the Honor 7x is not compatible with Fitbit devices. It will not sync no matter what and searching for the problem reveals that everyone else with this phone is experiencing the same problem. I'm not sure if it’s a problem with the phone or Fitbit. Based on my research, both the Bluetooth and Wi-Fi share the same antenna on this phone. Anytime the phone is restarted, the Bluetooth is automatically disabled and has to be re-enabled.

Pros include a beautiful and large screen with small bezels, great performance, and premium build quality.

Cons include no NFC (used for mobile payments), no 5G Wi-Fi support, and Micro-USB instead of USB-C.

Sadly, I had to return the phone due to a lack of compatibility with my Fitbit Charge 2. My recommendation to anyone purchasing this phone is to test it with your Bluetooth devices before investing a significant amount of time configuring everything else.

This being my first Huawei I was a little skeptical however the reviews provided me some encouragement. I really like the design and although not as wide as my LG, it still fit in my leather phone case, which is a personal "perk' for me.
Setup was a cinch. The device instructions are EASY to understand. The Huawei is the most programmable phone I've had. You can set your preference on just about anything. My one negative on this and it may be operator error, is I can't seem to figure out how to set an individual text-tone. Ringtones, yes, but texting.....?
The Huawei has an "easy eye" feature that blocks out the blue light for easy reading. Wonderful addition! So much so that my wife, having a history of Migraines, purchased her own Huawei and it's on the way. This feature and the matte screen protector, I purchased, reduces the glare considerably. Another added feature I like is the dual sim. With this option I will be able to purchase a prepaid SIM card for when we travel outside of the U.S. on our vacations. No more adding the international plan or buying a cheap burn-phone when I get off the plane. This phone has a dual camera function and, for me, it takes great pics. Ulasan:
Update/Edit: After the number of issues I've had with this phone I decided to do even more research on it, including checking benchmark scores. I wish I had done that first! This phone scores abysmally! Yes, it's a $200 phone and should not perform as well as a $500 phone... but keep in mind that you're taking a HUGE performance hit. (About 1/3 to 1/5 as fast as phones in the 400-500 dollar range.) If you have all the time in the world and don't care about performance of your phone or how long it takes to open apps, particularly the camera, then go ahead and waste your money on this.

Though, I will admit that this phone does have two pros. First, the screen is quite nice. The color reproduction is good, the brightness is reasonable (I can see it outside in all but the brightest conditions), and the resolution is quite pretty. Second (and lastly), It puts up with abuse. I have dented the back of the phone, through the case I have on it, and it still functions as good as ever (which is to say, sadly, still awful), and the screen is still intact. Which is unfortunate because I've been hoping to break it so I have an excuse to buy a new phone. Oh well. I went ahead and bought a Mi MIX 2s anyhow.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
First off, I bought this off of hihonor.com - the manufacturer's website for their phones - because the phone was back ordered on Amazon for like a month.

Having said that... this phone is simply no good.

I wouldn't say I had high expectations for the phone necessarily (it's $200 after all), but I definitely didn't expect my streaming app to constantly stop or hiccup, whether on WiFi or 4G. I also didn't expect to have to wait 30 seconds or more for the camera to be ready to use, nor did I expect it to be inoperable once it was on the screen (pressing the shutter doesn't always work... sometimes it takes a LONG time to respond, sometimes it doesn't respond). Then when it does finally work the quality of pictures is subpar. Sorry, let me correct that, in full blazing daylight the pictures look great. Good color and great detail. I can see the individual strands of fur on my dogs. However, if there's a single cloud in the sky the pictures are awful. Heaven forbid you try to take night or indoor shots.

Another big issue is that the alarm app. doesn't work. I have no idea why... it just doesn't. I had to download a third party alarm app. to even use the alarm on the phone. I tested this multiple times and multiple ways (alarm vs. timer, overnight vs. a few minutes, etc.) and the alarm only sounds if, and only if, you manually turn the screen on while it should be going off. So, in other words, if you don't manually turn the screen on at 6AM when the alarm goes off, you'll never know it's going off. Yup! Fun stuff.

Want to turn down your phone? TOO BAD! This only lets you turn down the call volume a little bit. The lowest volume is still eardrum blastingly loud. I'm quite certain the 30 minute call I just had damaged my hearing. (Yes, this sounds like I'm being a bit dramatic but I assure you it's still very loud. And to top that off my supervisor speaks loudly, which is why I SHOULD BE ABLE TO TURN DOWN THE VOLUME... but alas, the brilliant minds at Huawei apparently know what's better for my ears than me.)

Sadly I threw away the box just a couple of days ago, so now I can no longer send it back. So, basically, I'm out $200 unless I can sell it and recoup some of my losses.

DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS PHONE. Seriously. Cough up a little bit more and get a better phone. This is a shame because the V10 looks like it might be a solid phone, but due to the issues with this I simply won't ever buy it.

Ulasan: Before I bought this phone, I read about how terribly it lagged, how it takes forever to open an app and how incredibly frustrating it is when you are trying to do something. I went and bought it anyway, directly from the honor store. It worked well the first week, then I started noticing some lagging the second week. This is my third week of ownership and the negatives far outweighs any benefits this phone has.
Label: Positif

Ulasan:
I needed the "best bang for the $" and after about a month of heavy online research and reviews I decided on this 7x...
I LOVE IT!
I do not require or want the new flagship device as I just do not use a phone enough to justify $1K on a phone but I wanted a good looking phone. I am happy to repot this phone looks like a very expensive phone! The huge 18:9 screen just shouts expensive!

I needed a good camera, I needed a minimum of 32 gb and a minimum 3 gb ram so this 7x delivers.
On my 1st day of using my phone "more than normal" as its new, I am at 57% at the end of the evening so looks like the battery life will be great for my normal use and will give me much more than a full day.

UPDATE: I have now had the phone a few weeks and with my light to average use ( I do not live on my phone) I noticed I was on day 3, 8 hours and still had a little battery left! So I know with how I use my phone, I will never be searching for a charger!

I am on t-mobil and happy to report the phone works well ( my other phones did not as I am in a bad t-mobil location) The voice over 4G does work and the voice quality is MUCH better than any phone I have used.

T-Mobil WiFi calling does not work with this phone. I have been using T-Mobil purchased phones with T-Mobil versions of Android and or iPhones but T-Mobil WIFI calling only works on iPhones and T-Mobil devices. After searching T-mobil does have a App ( T-Mobil DIGITS) That allows calling / texting via a internet connection so I expect the WIFI calling will be a non-issue for me. I did use WIFI calling the few times I vacation in the mountains with no cell signal but now that I have a Digits app I'm okay.

This phone wifi will only do 2.4 ghz, not 5.0 ghz but I have improved my home wifi with a mesh system and I find most hotspots around town use the 2.4. My phone is very fast however when I do a wifi speed test I do not get the speed I do with a 5.0 ghz phone but the 7X phone is actually a faster phone? I would like to see dual band WIFI and I considered another brand because of only 2.4 but the other brand at this price point did not have this beautiful screen size so I am very happy I purchased this phone.

When purchasing this phone I also wanted a case and a glass screen protector, These Amazon products fit PERFECT and love them as much as the phone! Huawei Honor 7X case, Yuanling [Shock Resistant] Carbon Fiber Soft TPU Brushed Texture Phone case Anti-fingerprint Flexible Full-body Protective Cover For Huawei Honor 7X smartphone (Blue)

This glass protector fits PERFECT with no bubbles and went on EZ, Best glass protector I have ever used so if you are buying the 7x, this is the one to buy!
[2 Pack]Huawei Honor 7X Screen Protector,Setber [Full Coverage][2.5D Arc Edges][9 Hardness][Anti-Scratch][Anti-fingerprint][HD Clear]Tempered Glass Screen Protector for Huawei Honor 7X -Blue

At this price point , My thoughts are with this grade of camera, battery life, edge to edge 18:9 screen ( makes phones with normal screens look ancient ) and the fact that it is reported the 7X will get the newest Android 8.0 Oreo, this phone is simply the phone to buy!
UPDATE: I have had this phone almost 1 year. I do love this phone. this is the only phone I have EVER used that has not locked up at least once on me! The operating system works PERFECT! The camera is much better than lots of more expensive phones. I own mega expensive pro cameras so I know! This phone camera may not be what is in a $1K phone but I would say almost! I like the camera, its looks fantastic.
Issues is using the phone in my home office. I have a new metal roof that blocks cell signal and I truly need Tmobil wifi calling. As I understand wifi calling is only on unlocked newer like 6+ iPhones or phones purchased from T-mobil so this phone can not do t-mobil wifi calling. I need this feature as I can't get good cell coverage at my home office. Tmobil has the digits app that somewhat helps but its a bummer I don't have wifi calling.
The lack of 5 ghz ( only 2.4 ghz ) makes for a slower wifi connection, not a deal breaker but on the new Honor phone its needs dual band wifi. needs to be USB c connector on the newer phone as well.
If you can live without wifi calling I still think this phone is the phone to buy! Almost a year and I still get 3+ days on a charge! Fantastic!
Label: Positif
